why it died and all the lessons learned along the way

Transition from Web 2 to Web 3. üîÅ

As the internet transitions from Web 2.0 to Web 3.0, new content will take the form of immersive experiences that link the digital environment with physical sensations. Web 3.0, which many experts use synonymously with the metaverse, promises to introduce novel types of content alongside a decentralized content culture.

The metaverse didn't die. It never took off. üõ¨

An immersive, seamless metaverse requires robust virtual reality and augmented reality systems. This hardware is neither accessible nor affordable. Because of the inability to address all these issues, a huge amount of content likely isn't being used.

Why does it feel so ... lazy? üí§

While technological limiations might be one of the reasons why digital art feels so artifical on the metaverse, it's not entirely the case. Another significant factor is the normalization of the tech industry and die-hard focus on cleanliness and simplicity.

Why does it matter now? ‚ÄºÔ∏è

A design vaccuum will appear when the technology does catch up. Analogous to attempts at Language Models in the 2000s, technology will reach a point where the first point, seamless virtual reality is possible. Rendering Web 3 content could become a new advertising venture.
